documents.title: that 's all for today
text: thanks everyone !
if you want more alexei , he 'll be appearing at two guardian events , what did the 80s do for us ?
on 18 may , and guardian live as part of the brighton festival on 27 may .
guardian contributor alexeisayle 16 march 2016 2:02pm thank you everybody for your questions .
buy my book !
i 'm in the guardian most days at the moment , so see you tomorrow , when i will be writing a long article about how the falling oil price will affect internal saudi politics .
simonsaint asks : i remember you doing a great little tv series about dancing about 15 years ago .
enjoyed it a lot .
are you still as enthusiastic or able ?
guardian contributor alexeisayle 16 march 2016 2:01pm i still love dancing , but i think i 'm too fat now .
but i still say i can salsa as well as any north london social worker .
clariana asks : you and omid djalili separated at birth ?
guardian contributor alexeisayle 16 march 2016 2:00pm omid 's got this story .
i was quite close to robin williams and ten years ago omid met robin several times , and each time robin said to omid : great to meet you again alexei .
rigmods hardware asks : why does george osbourne have talons instead of fingers ?
guardian contributor alexeisayle 16 march 2016 1:59pm good observation .
but i would n't open with it .

themoralmanager asks : my alcohol-addled brain recalls that the opening title 's for as stuff series 2 were a pastiche of the mickey mouse show who 's that big fat bastard did you receive any communications from disney 's lawyers ?
guardian contributor alexeisayle 16 march 2016 1:58pm yes , not for that so much , but i wrote a sketch called snow white and the seven samurai .
and they threatened to sue us for htat .
and we went to see the bbc barrister and i expected her to be all legalese but she just said : `` fuck disney , we 're the bbc . ''
i do love the opening titles though , sometimes i sing them to myself .
`` we love to hear him swear on tv `` the girl who says `` who 's that fat bastard '' is a six year old cheryl tweedy !
at least i think it is i read it on the internet you see .
mikeblewes asks : does poetry have any use ?
guardian contributor alexeisayle 16 march 2016 1:56pm i think one of the things that is lacking in me is i do n't appreciate poetry sufficiently .
i used to teach sometimes at the arvon foundation and they told me the only time they 'd ever had a fight between teachers was several times on poetry courses .
which i kind of like .
i 'm a fan of obvious stuff : larkin , duffy , and kate tempest i like .
and an old friend of mine , benjamin zephaniah .
but anything more abstruse anything pre-20th century .
which is a bit crass - i 'd like to see what people see in milton or browning or wordsworth , but i do n't get it , which is a failing in me .
pbcc asks : have you been nominated for a gong or even offered one ?
if not , why the delay ?
guardian contributor alexeisayle 16 march 2016 1:53pm well , the short answer is no .
and i do n't believe in the honours system .
in the blair years they would test you out .

first of all you would be invited to a drinks party at 17 downing street ; then if they liked you you 'd be invited to 15 , 14 downing street , and have champagne with blair i would never take an honour though .
unless it was the order of lenin .

documents.title: 'enlightenment ideas are , despite what you read in the papers , slowly gaining a grip all over the world '
text: itsuptous asks : i think one of the things some intelligent and compassionate people struggle with is how beautiful life is and yet how much suffering there is .
we could , as a species , build societies filled with fairness , love and kindness ; so much suffering that people have to endure is unnecessary .
i think your humour reflects that wisdom , love and anger ; how do you stay positive knowing what you know ?
guardian contributor alexeisayle 16 march 2016 1:52pm it 's difficult really - i agree with what you say .
and my solution is to laugh at cruelties in the world , try and mine humour from them .
and if we ever did have a society based on love and compassion and fairness , i worry that i 'd be out of a job .
there 's a narrative that certain philosophers have , that shit be getting better - that enlightenment ideas are , despite what you read in the papers , are slowly gaining a grip all over the world .
if that 's the case , then i think it 's a race between enlightenment ideas and climate catastrophe .
let 's see who wins .

documents.title: 'the comedian who 's really astonished me in the last few years is louis ck '
text: crosseyedandpainless asks : who is your favourite comedian ?
guardian contributor alexeisayle 16 march 2016 1:49pm the comedian who i 've seen in the last few years who 's really astonished me was louis ck .
i just thought what he was doing was just brilliant , really .
it 's very humane , but also kind of bleak at the same time .
i like chris rock too .
i 'm not particularly well up on comedians though i do also very much admire the guardian 's very own stewart lee .
his new tv series is fantastic .
he 's just very clever , but it 's funny , and from one professional to another , he 's very dedicated to the craft - he puts the hours in , in a way that i do n't .
noahguggenheim asks : you say that you were trying to get to the top of the entertainment business but is n't great comedy , like all great art just telling a good story .
i 'm not naã¯ve ( well hopefully ) but i balk at entertainment being an industry .
the funniest things i have ever heard were stories my father told me round the dinner table .
at the end of them he never passed a cap around for us to throw coins in .
so my question is were you at any stage in it for the money or was it about the communication with people .
guardian contributor alexeisayle 16 march 2016 1:47pm i would agree with what you say in a way - that the greatest humour is often simply between people .
and it was that humour that i was attempting to exploit , and monetise , for my own raging ambition .
as well as the interaction between people , which is great , there 's a demand for professional comedy as well , and that 's what i was : a professional comedian .
professional comedy is just different - it 's still possible to communicate a powerful message .
thepeoplespoet asks : how did you feel when stephen fry , hugh laurie , mel smith , griff rhys jones and emma thompson infiltrated the young ones ?
guardian contributor alexeisayle 16 march 2016 1:44pm it 's in the book , thank you for asking .
i said to the writers , what are these people doing here ?
are n't they the enemy ?
they replied : no that 's just you , we think they 're lovely .
theblueacorn asks : your old colleague david stafford did a great job taking over home truths when peel died .
have you ever fancied fully embracing an avuncular radio 4 style family presenting role ?
you would be very good .
otherwise , please tell us more about your book , its title and where one can get it from ( hint : public library , where i work ) .

guardian contributor alexeisayle 16 march 2016 1:43pm the book is called thatcher stole my trousers and you can get it at waterstones , amazon , or your local independent bookstore - such as news from nowhere , just up the road from where i had a conversation about a flat white on bold street , liverpool .
yes , i agree , david did a very good job of taking over from peel .
i think the viewing figures went up , but they cancelled the show anyway .
i would have liked to have tried being that kind of host , of radio and tv shows , but nobody ever offered it to me really .
i guess there 's still time .
i ca n't see myself doing another sketch show - i do n't have the time or the energy i 'd need to invest in that .
documentaries i 'd like to make , but i do n't really have ideas in my head .
i write about cars , and i was talking to an iranian director a few weeks ago .

the main car still more or less in iran was called a paykan , which was a hillman which had been made in britain - i think the story of how that car went from coventry to iran would make a fascinating story for example .
basically anything gruff rhys-jones does , i could do better .

documents.title: 'i 'm in love with the `` genre '' of football '
text: trampas asks : one thing i never did quite get from your first book is whether you support liverpool or everton .
you seemed to be hedging .
i only ask because as a united fan i 'd like to know whether or not i 'm technically supposed to be your bitterest enemy , in which case i 'd have to tear up my kindle .
or maybe you could send me a hammer ?
guardian contributor alexeisayle 16 march 2016 1:38pm this is a very wussy , north london liberal answer , but i 'm in love with the `` genre '' of football .
i used to alternate between liverpool and everton but neither of them took .
i 'd like to be a football fan , i think i 'm missing out by not having an attachment to a particular team , but i can just never quite see the sense in it .
on and off i 've supported england over the years - that makes more sense to me .
also , as a manchester united fan you have my sympathies .
i met a guy once in australia and he told me he was a newcastle supporter , i said why , are you family from there ?
he said no , i support any team that plays in black and white stripes .
he supported newcastle , juventus , and there was an aussie rules team called hawthorn i think .
which i thought was an interesting choice .

documents.title: 'the only thing i draw now is guns '
text: stanley park asks : alexei , do you still do any sketches or artwork ?
i 'm thinking in particular of your sketches in great bus journeys of the world .
guardian contributor alexeisayle 16 march 2016 1:35pm no - the only thing i draw now , and i mention this in thatcher , is guns .
i could knock you up a sketch of an m-16 .
because my parents would n't allow me to have guns as a kid , so i 've become an expert .
xokatyxo asks : what are some of your favourite memories of ( the ) rik mayall ?
guardian contributor alexeisayle 16 march 2016 1:34pm this is n't really a memory of rik , but a memory of peter o'toole .
one of rik 's favourite showbiz anecdotes was that peter o'toole shared a house with richard harris , and o'toole had a very small part in his first movie .
his call time was 6.30am , and richard harris gets up at 9 and o'toole is still sitting there in the flat .
richard harris says : why are you still here ?
and o'toole says : i 'm waiting for my taxi .
and finally the production rings up and asks where he is , and peter o'toole shouts down the phone : no taxi , no o'toole !
slams the phone down .
rik used to often tell that story .
i think it chimed with his own beliefs .
pf77 asks : do you think short stories are under-valued as an art form ?
barcelona plates and the dogcatcher are two of my favourite books but few writers seem to devote much of their time on short stories , preferring full-length novels ( as you moved on to ) .
guardian contributor alexeisayle 16 march 2016 1:31pm short stories are not popular with the public either !
it 's odd - you 'd think in this age , people would like them , short little nuggety stories , but they do n't really seem to .
i love writing them and i have an idea for my next book which will be sort of short stories , but all of them linked .
i do think also as well that when people are writing about short stories - i 'm talking to you , guardian - i seem to get left out .
when i am in fact , according to me , the bestselling short story author in britain since the war .

documents.title: 'jeremy [ corbyn ] is just an honest , ascetic , kind individual . whether a party led by someone with those qualities can prosper , it 's hard to say '
text: mandrakeman asks : what do you think the labour party needs to do to become a credible voting option for people in all parts of the uk , particularly middle england where they need to win back many votes and scotland where they have been wiped out ?
and , do you think we will ever have a social revolution in these islands which dislodges the aristocracy , all of it , the royals , the tories , the 1 % etc .
so , we get a government that works for the betterment of the whole population ?

guardian contributor alexeisayle 16 march 2016 1:28pm as i said in my article in the guardian on saturday , i think it 's important that if you 're a political comedian , you do n't ally yourself with any one political party .
nevertheless i 'm obviously know and like jeremy corbyn .
all the leaders of the left before through the 70s and 80s had terrible , terrible character flaws .

there 's a wonderful bit in tracey thorn 's memoir in which he and ben from everything but the girl are asked to write a new anthem for the labour party and meet with leading leftwing liverpool mp eric heffer , and she just paints him as this extraordinary philistine , bombastic fool .
he 's somebody used to come round our house , somebody our parents knew .
jeremy does n't have that bombast , he does n't have those character flaws .
he 's just an honest , ascetic , kind individual .
whether a party led by someone with those qualities can prosper , it 's hard to say .
but i think it 's an interesting time .

documents.title: 'who 'd think flat whites could ever happen on liverpool 's bold street ? '
text: condorkelly says : i looked after your mum one time years ago and she was a star , but what would she think of the liverpool today ?
and yourself , any opinions on it ?

by the way , last time i saw you ( well over 20+ years ago ) you were cycling down upper parliament street ( surprisingly not up it ) and i shouted , al right lexi , to which you respond al right la .
treasured memory .

guardian contributor alexeisayle 16 march 2016 1:23pm first of all , the night my mother died , we knew she was still herself - the neighbours had heard her shouting at the home helps through the wall .
molly never expressed much opinion about modern liverpool .
i personally , i will always be upset that they knocked so much of it down but on the other hand , certainly the centre of town seems very vibrant and full of tourists which is strange .
it 's one of britain 's major tourist destinations now .
it 's just different now .
last time i was there , i had a long conversation with a barista in a coffee shop of bold street about the best way to make a flat white .
who 'd think that could ever happen on bold street ?
puncrock asks : hello mr sayle , i 'd love to see those short films you made in art school .
are they still about ?
ps .
ignore the questions from self-righteous , attention-seeking , plazzy blairite commentators , they derive happiness only through the misfortune of others , the schadenfeckers .
guardian contributor alexeisayle 16 march 2016 1:20pm i 'm not sure if i still have them , or the guy i made them with has them .
but they 're on a very strange format called standard 8 , so i do n't know how you 'd show them .
maybe one day they 're sort of funny little weird arty films , mostly about art itself .
it was me and another guy at st martins - we hated art films and performance art , and nearly everything that was going on at art school .
so we made films about that .
hvadaltsaa asks : do you feel that you were misunderstood in you early days as a comedian around the time of the young ones and were you ever mistaken as a skinhead ?
guardian contributor alexeisayle 16 march 2016 1:17pm on an early standup tour , i was in southend , and the front row was all nazi skinheads .
i said to them from the stage : i think you 've got the wrong gig - i 'm a communist jew .
and they said : we do n't care .
after the show they came backstage and they seemed charming .
it was a look , it was a determinedly working class look , so some people chose it for that .

documents.title: 'if i ever made a slip-up it was more to do with fame , i think . it leads you to make mistakes '
text: letthemsnortcoke asks : at what age do you think it is appropriate to sell out ?
do you think people notice when they sell out ?
i mean do you think there is a conscious point where people say aw fuck it or do you think that it is insidious and creeps up on you and you only notice in retrospect .
incidentally i 'm not being snarky and implying that you have sold out but rather that you held firm and rather radical views when you were younger .
as such it will be more noticeable in your associates .
some people with such views often do a full 180 when they get older too - the hitchens brothers spring to mind as do the people that became the neocons in the us .
any thoughts ?
guardian contributor alexeisayle 16 march 2016 1:15pm it 's an interesting question .
i do n't think there 's an appropriate age to sell out .
indeed , my book thatcher stole my trousers is a kind of account of me trying to get to the top of the entertainment business , and not sell out .
i do n't think i necessarily managed that , but i always attempting to do it .
i 'm also fascinated by the idea of the apostate : the people who do start out left and become right .
and as i say in the book , it 's not a journey - they start out as one kind of twat and end up as another kind of twat .

people like christopher hitchens i think when you start out the people you want attention from are all left-wing , but then when you get older you start craving those things that only right-wing people can give you : money , i suppose ; power .
in this country , honours .
sometimes i 've found myself seduced by that - if i ever made a slip-up it was more to do with fame , i think .
it leads you to make mistakes , i think .
i still do n't know what i was doing in carry on columbus .
but i 've never done anything i 've been ashamed of either as a writer or as a standup , which will do for me .
brothercrow asks : was it you who cast future oscar winner christoph waltz in series two of the all new alexei sayle show ?
guardian contributor alexeisayle 16 march 2016 1:10pm yes , and future doctor who peter capaldi .
in fact if you look on christoph 's imdb television listing for 1996 the only thing on it is weak moustache on the all new alexei sayle show .
me and christoph , we were very close friends .
we did a comedy series together about the eu , written by malcolm bradbury , called the gravy train , and we got on very well and became very good friends .
i always like to cast friends when i can .
he 's an amazingly intelligent man , an astonishing linguist .
as you saw in his breakthrough in inglorious basterds , he has an incredible facility with languages .
he comes from this family of really high-achieving viennese , and is just extraordinarily knowledgeable about virtually everything , i think .
he 's grown into his looks too - he always had that drive to be a star , but when he was younger he kind of looked odd .
now he 's very handsome .
and a wonderful actor .
halloway asks : which are you closer to spiritually : the brothers karamazov or the chuckle brothers ?
guardian contributor alexeisayle 16 march 2016 1:07pm i do n't know much about either , really .
i think i saw the brothers karamazov at the glasgow empire .
id0480360 asks : what should i get for lunch ?
guardian contributor alexeisayle 16 march 2016 1:06pm as the owner of an imaginary sandwich bar , we find ourselves under threat from all manner of street food : pulled pork , jollof rice , pho .
i recommend you go to an old-fashioned sandwich bar and have a coronation chicken sandwich that comes from a big vat of gloop , on white bread , with margarine .

documents.title: 'the only writer i go back to over and over is evelyn waugh '
text: danny marsh asks : having read your short stories and novels , i am wondering who your favourite writers are .
which short story writers do you admire ?
i had a dream that we met and had a lengthy discussion on some metal steps at the bbc where you stated your love for gogol .
guardian contributor alexeisayle 16 march 2016 1:04pm well , the only writer i go back to over and over is evelyn waugh .
one of the things i 've always tried to do is listen to other voices .
my parents tended to only read stuff that confirmed their point of view , and i was more interested in stuff that came from the opposite point of view .
it 's important to challenge your own viewpoint .
waugh disliked the working classes , there are no working class characters in his novels , but for all that he was a wonderful satirist .
if i went on celebrity mastermind , my specialist subject would be the sword of honour series .
i would get 9 points out of a possible 13 .
squeezybox asks : you are well known for your sharp , deadly accurate political satire in the 1980s .
we do n't get that from you now , but for god 's sake we could do with it .
do you think you are too much of a national treasure to pillory the twats in charge now , or are you too old , or do you think no-one will take any interest ?
or do n't you car anymore ?
guardian contributor alexeisayle 16 march 2016 1:02pm i do n't think i 'm a national treasure , really .
but when i went back and did standup comedy for 100 dates in 2012-13 i found myself still doing a lot of satire .
obviously , doing satire in a memoir of the 1980s seems a bit pointless , although i do comment on it all .
i still do care , and if i do more standup i 'll do more satire .
and i 'm doing a radio series in the autumn for radio 4 called alexei sayle 's imaginary sandwich bar and a lot of that i think will be about politics .
i 'm more interested in the broader psychological motivation for why people have the beliefs they have .
we 'll see .

text: here he is , at guardian towers and questions in hand .
let 's start !
alexei sayle beaumont-thomas

documents.title: post your questions for alexei sayle
text: as master of ceremonies at the comedy store , firing explosive scorn at the audience and standups alike , alexei sayle heralded the start of the alternative comedy boom of the 1980s .
having grown up in a communist family in liverpool , political anger stoked his material , and his hilarious irascibility was soon fed into a huge range of pursuits .

as well as producing the emmy-winning sketch show alexei sayle 's stuff , he 's acted in everything from doctor who to indiana jones , the young ones and the tempest , and enjoyed a brief flirtation with the pop charts , scoring a hit with absurdist punk song ullo john , got a new motor ?
he is also the author of five novels and two volumes of memoirs .
with the latest memoir out this month , entitled thatcher stole my trousers , alexei is joining us to answer your questions about anything in his career , from 1pm gmt on wednesday 16 march .
post them in the comments below , and he 'll answer as many as possible .
